text: Integrating Motivational Interviewing Into a Home Telehealth Program for Veterans With Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Who Smoke: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: We evaluated integrating a motivational interviewing (MI)-based smoking cessation cur-ricula and MI counseling into a posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) home telehealth care management program to determine if smoking behaviors improved.
Method: We randomized 178 Veterans with PTSD to a 90 - session MI-based home telehealth program or to usual care.
Outcome measures included self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts, seven-day point prevalence abstinence, progression along the stages of change, and mental health symptoms.
Results: Favorable smoking cessation rates were observed in both groups.
There was no statistical difference in self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts , seven-day point prevalence smoking abstinence or progression along the stages of change.
The intervention group showed improved depression and PTSD symptoms.
Conclusion: Integrating MI-based smoking cessation treatment into PTSD home telehealth is an effective method to help Veterans with PTSD quit smoking.
Further research is needed to understand how to optimize MI integration into home telehealth to achieve sustained smoking cessation rates.
Attendance at smoking cessation programs is low, with Veterans citing inconvenient time, lack of desire to quit, and lengthy distances as main barriers for attendance).
Furthermore, 55% of Veterans Health Administration (VHA) patients who smoke do not want to quit), indicating that different or more intense motivational strategies are needed.
An easily accessible program that integrates mental health treatment and targets increased motivation to quit maybe needed to address and overcome these barriers.
Home telehealth with care management increases access by providing at-home monitoring and coordination with a nurse.
Aligned with the principles of the chronic care model), home telehealth has been shown to improve symptoms and increase both self-management behaviors and knowledge about a chronic condition).
Nationally, VHA uses home telehealth services fora variety of chronic diseases, including PTSD, depression, heart failure, and diabetes.
Integration of smoking cessation treatment into mental health clinics has been shown to effectively increase quit rates (.
However, the incorporation of smoking cessation care into home telehealth disease management programs has not been tested.

Motivational Interviewing (MI) is a patient-centered counseling style that aims to facilitate behavior change by helping individuals explore and resolve ambivalence, a common barrier to making a behavior change.
Previous studies have shown MI to bean effective smoking cessation counseling style).

The transtheoretical model of change (TTM) describes change as occurring by an individual progressing through stages (precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, action, and maintenance), from no interest in making a change (pre-contemplation) to sustained changeover time (maintenance), and has been validated for use in smoking populations.
MI is used as a method of communication to help people move through the stages of change.
This study tested the effectiveness of a home telehealth care management program on smoking cessation rates in Veterans with PTSD.

We hypothesized that integrating MI-based smoking cessation curricula into an established PTSD home telehealth program would increase the proportion of self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts, seven-day point prevalence (PP) smoking abstinence and progression along the stages of change compared with the PTSD home telehealth program alone.
We also monitored suicidal thoughts, PTSD, and depression symptoms to assess any changes between Veterans receiving integrated care and those receiving usual care.
This pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) was designed to test the effectiveness of an intervention that could be easily implemented into current practice.
We received institutional review board approval for this study.
The study was conducted at a VHA healthcare system that included both urban and rural outpatient clinics.
A total of 178 participants were enrolled from the 4,327 people who were assessed for eligibility).
Participants were recruited using informational flyers, provider referrals, and outreach letters.
The majority (n = 110) were recruited from outreach letters.

Inclusion criteria were Veterans who (a) were 18 years of age or older, (b) had a Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders IV criteria for diagnosis code 309.81 PTSD documented in their medical record, and (c) were currently smoking one or more cigarettes per day at the time of recruitment.
All smokers were invited to participate, regardless of their desire to quit.

Veterans were excluded if they (a) used smokeless tobacco, pipes, or cigars instead of cigarettes, (b) had imminent risk of suicide or violence, (c) had severe psychiatric symptoms or cognitive impairment likely to prevent participation in protocol (assessed by their mental health or primary care provider), or (d) lacked telephone access or were unable to connect to the telehealth device in their home.

Participants were randomized to either the control group, receiving the PTSD home telehealth care management program and nurse care management alone, or the intervention group, receiving the PTSD home telehealth care management program and nurse care management PLUS MI-based written smoking cessation curricula on home telehealth and weekly telephonic smoking cessation MI counseling by a nurse).

Both groups had access to currently offered VHA smoking cessation treatments, including nicotine replacement therapy (patch, lozenge, gum, and inhaler), bupropion, varenicline, tobacco cessation clinic, support groups, and classes.
A research pharmacist who was unaffiliated with the study performed randomization using a blocked randomization process.
Study personnel were blinded to the randomization process.

Both study groups received PTSD home telehealth care management services with a device called the Health Buddy (Bosch Healthcare, Palo Alto, CA), which is designed to help individuals with PTSD self-monitor and self-manage.
This computer-like device is 12 × 8 × 4 inches with a LCD screen, on which patients read information, and four large buttons for responding to questions.
A typical session is completed in approximately 2 minutes.
Participants were asked to read the information and then answer self-monitoring and knowledge-based questions on the Health Buddy everyday.
Examples of monitored symptoms were anxiety, stress, anger, and depression.
Patients' responses were then automatically transmitted overnight to a secure data center and the next day's curriculum was downloaded to the device.
Both intervention and control nurse care managers (CM), who logged onto a secure VHA Intranet site, read patients' responses daily during the regular workweek.
Nurse CMs monitored changes in health status, placed outreach phone calls to patients with urgent needs, and coordinated care with primary medical and/or mental health providers.
The control nurse CM provided only home telehealth care management to Veterans with PTSD.
Intervention nurse CMs were trained in care management for Veterans with PTSD and MI counseling techniques.
A quality assurance process was implemented to ensure intervention nurse CMs delivered the intervention consistently.
We designed the intervention period to be completed in 12 weeks (90 sessions) and the follow-up period to be completed in 6 months (sessions 91 to 270).
Participants had the option to stop using the Health Buddy during the follow-up period.
The smoking cessation curricula and counseling were based on the TTM () with the goal of helping participants progress along the stages of change.
The TTM framework was used to assess participants' desire to make a change and MI was used to provide a customized response.
The members of the research team used MI material for healthcare providers to write the MI-based smoking cessation curricula.
A participant's response to a question dictated a different reply based on his or her stage of change.
Research has shown that tailoring the therapy relationship and treatment intervention to stage of change can improve outcomes).

The intervention nurse CMs used these responses to understand the quitting process, promote the identified health behavior change, and help participants acquire a positive behavior (tobacco cessation).
During the intervention period, MI counseling sessions occurred weekly with intervention participants.
During those calls, the intervention nurse CMs assessed the stage of change and
This study is unique in several ways.
We integrated smoking cessation care into an established telehealth program for mental health monitoring and treatment.
Smoking cessation curricula are adaptable to other home telehealth devices and diagnoses.
MI has not been tested for smoking cessation treatment in a population with PTSD.
We optimized MI dose by providing both MIbased written curricula via telehealth and MI telephone counseling.
By employing a patientcentered perspective, we enabled individuals with PTSD to partake in cessation counseling in their home, eliminating physical and emotional barriers to clinic visits.
Finally, broad inclusion criteria allowed all smokers to participate, even those who expressed little or no desire to make a change.
Our control group had seven-day PP abstinence consistent with intervention group outcomes in other PTSD smoking cessation studies (.
We hypothesize the control group achieved these rates as a result of receiving more than usual care.
Most participants in both groups received the Health Buddy for the first time when they joined the study.
Thus, the control group interacted daily with the Health Buddy, leading to an increased focus on self-monitoring and healthy choices.
The control group was also asked to recall smoking behaviors and stage of change on the Health Buddy.
Recall questions used the principles of MI, resulting in the control group having exposure to the core tenets of MI.
We wanted both groups to use the PTSD telehealth program to determine how enhancement facilitates cessation.
Additionally, we wanted to facilitate data collection.
We believe these factors increased awareness of smoking behaviors for the control group, leading to increased cessation.
Baseline (Time 1) data included demographics, nicotine addiction, PTSD and depression symptoms, stage of change, and medical and mental health diagnoses in the medical record.
Four outcomes were measured: self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts, seven-day PP abstinence, stage of change, and mental health symptoms.
Smoking cessation outcome data, stage of change, and suicidal thoughts were collected during the intervention period using preprogrammed questions via the Health Buddy.
Participants in both groups were asked smoking cessation questions at specified intervals.
Smoking cessation outcome data and stage of change were also measured during the follow-up period using the same questions via the Health Buddy or monthly telephone calls.
PTSD and depression symptoms were measured at the end of both the intervention period (T2) and the follow-up period (T3).
Data collection questions were written using MI, including open-ended questions and affirmations.
Self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts and seven-day PP abstinence.
We measured a change in smoking behavior with the proportion of participants in each group who self-reported at least one 24 - hour quit attempt.
This was selected as the primary outcome because an increase in the number of quit attempts typically increases the number of abstainers overtime ().
We also examined seven-day PP abstinence, which we defined as the prevalence of abstinence during a window of time immediately preceding follow-up (.
Abstinence was verified using an exhaled carbon monoxide (CO) level at both T2 and T3.
A CO level of less than or equal to 10 parts per million was considered a nonsmoker ().
Self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts and seven-day PP abstinence outcome measures were collected every seven sessions via the Health Buddy in both groups during the intervention period.
Participants were asked, "Did you smoke any cigarettes (even a puff) in the last 24 hours?"
If no, then the participants read, "That is a benefit to your health," and were asked the number of days since their last cigarette.
If yes, then the participant read, "How many cigarettes did you smoke (even a puff) in the last 24 hours?"
If participants smoked the same number as usual, then they read, "Smoking is your choice and it is respected."
If participants smoked fewer, then they read, "This is an important change.
Please take time to congratulate yourself on this change.
You can talk to your nurse during your next call."
If participants smoked fewer or no cigarettes, data were collected on the use of VHA smoking cessation treatments.
If they smoked more, then they read, "This is an important change.
You can talk to your nurse during your next call."
Stage of change data were collected every 30 sessions via the Health Buddy in both groups during the intervention.
We measured stage of change using the TTM Stages of Change (short form) questionnaire.
We measured progression along the stages of change via the participant moving toward the action stage.
We monitored mental health symptoms during the study because cessation has been associated with worsening symptoms.
We assessed PTSD symptoms using the PTSD Checklist.
The PTSD Checklist has a range of 17 - 85 with a score > 50, indicating
We used the 15 - item Geriatric Depression Scale-Short Form (GDS-SF) to monitor depression.
A score greater than 6 indicates probable depression.
The GDS-SF has been shown to be valid in a younger population.
We assessed suicidal thoughts every 30 sessions during the intervention period with a question on the Health Buddy: "Are you having any thoughts of harming yourself?"
If a participant answered yes, then the nurse CM assessed for imminent risk and coordinated care with the mental health provider as needed.
We targeted 120 study completers to achieve 80% power in detecting a 25 percentage point difference fora two-sided test of proportions at Type I error rate = 0.05.
To achieve the targeted number of completers after attrition, 178 participants were consented to be in the study.
Final analyses were completed on 175 participants, as three enrollees were found to not be eligible after consent.
We performed all analyses using intent-to-treat principles.
Participants who were lost to follow-up or withdrew were considered continuing smokers during data analysis.
Analyses were performed using SAS (version 9.2).
Both univariable (considering only treatment) and multivariable analyses (additionally controlling for other covariates) were conducted at their relevant time points for all outcomes.

In the adjusted models, demographics, use of nicotine replacement or smoking cessation medication, mental health diagnoses, and nicotine addiction were variables considered for inclusion in the regression model.
Because of the large number of potential covariates and the small sample size, univariable analyses were first conducted on potential covariates to determine any difference between groups.
If a difference was significant at a 0.25 level, then that variable was included as a candidate predictor in the multiple regression models.
Higher order interactions were not analyzed and only a limited number of explanatory variables were considered in the models.

Variables included in all models were as follows: age, gender, lives alone, sessions completed, diagnosis of nicotine addiction, traumatic brain injury diagnosis, sexual abuse diagnosis, anxiety diagnosis, use of nicotine replacement therapy, PTSD Checklist score, and study completion.
During the intervention period, 24 - hour quit attempt models also included nicotine addiction score, GDS-SF score, and diagnosis of bipolar disorder.
During the follow-up period, 24 - hour quit attempt models also included employment status, nicotine addiction score, GDS-SF score, and diagnosis of tobacco dependence.
During the intervention period, seven-day PP models also included employment status and education level.
During the follow-up period, seven-day PP models also included employment status, education level, GDS-SF score, and nicotine addiction score.
We described baseline characteristics using means with standard deviations (SDs) and proportions with frequencies.

We compared differences between groups using t-tests (or Wilcoxon tests if skewed) for continuous variables and chi-square tests (or Fisher's exact tests if expected cell counts were small) for categorical variables.
We compared self-reported 24 - hour quit attempts, seven-day PP abstinence, and progression along the stages of change using dichotomous variables (1 = yes or 0 = no).
We analyzed differences between study groups using chi-square tests during the intervention and follow-up periods.
To improve the precision of estimates, the primary hypothesis was also tested using a logistic regression model following the modeling process described above.
To assess for any bias in the intent to treat principle, we conducted sensitivity analyses assuming those who had not responded had a 24 - hour quit attempt or seven-day PP abstinence.
Risk difference (RD) between groups with 95% confidence intervals (CI) was calculated.

We assessed mental health symptoms using mean scores and compared differences between groups using t tests (or nonparametric tests where the normality assumption was violated) and linear regression models.
The study groups were statistically similar except for the presence of an anxiety diagnosis).
Most participants were male, White, older than 50 years, and unemployed.

At T1, many participants were in the contemplation (57.3% intervention and 53.5% control) or preparation (29.2% intervention and 30.2% control) stages, had a medium dependence on nicotine, scored > 50 on the PTSD Checklist, and scored > 6 on the GDS-SF.
A total of 120 participants) completed the study (61 intervention and 59 control).
Participants who completed the study were statistically similar to those who voluntarily withdrew except forage, with more completers being older than 50 years (p < 0.01).
No significant difference was found in the unadjusted analysis of 24 - hour quit attempts during the intervention and follow-up periods.

During the intervention period, 38.2% of the intervention group reported at least one 24 - hour quit attempt and 32.6% of the control group reported at least one 24 - hour quit attempt (unadjusted p = 0.44, adjusted p = 0.83).
The RD was 5.6% (95% CI).
At T2, a CO level confirmed cessation for 81.8% of participants (p = 0.22).
Sensitivity analysis indicated no significant difference (p = 0.33).
During the follow-up period, 27.0% of the intervention group and 36.1% of the control group reported at least one 24 - hour quit attempt (unadjusted p = 0.20; adjusted p = 0.06).
The RD was -9.1% (95% CI).
At T3, a CO level confirmed cessation for 67.9% of the participants (p = 0.27).
Sensitivity analysis indicated no significant difference (p = 0.94).
No significant difference in seven-day PP smoking abstinence was found between the intervention and control groups during the intervention and the follow-up periods.
During the intervention period, 22.5% of the intervention group and 25.6% of the control group reported seven-day PP abstinence (unadjusted p = 0.63; adjusted p = 0.26).
The RD was -3.1% (95% CI).
At T2, a CO level confirmed cessation for 90.4% of the participants (p = 1.00).
Sensitivity analysis indicated no significant difference (p = 0.63).
During the follow-up, 23.6% of the intervention group and 23.3% of the control group reported seven-day PP abstinence (unadjusted p = 0.96; adjusted p = 0.81).
The RD was 0.30% (95% CI).
At T3, a CO level confirmed cessation for 69.6% of the participants (p = 0.41).
Sensitivity analysis indicated no significant difference (p = 0.96).
No significant difference in progression along the stages of change was found between study groups during the intervention and follow-up periods.
During the intervention period, 40.4% of the intervention group and 40.7% of the control group made a progression along the stages of change (unadjusted p = 0.97; adjusted p = 0.26).
The RD was -0.3% (95% CI).
During the follow-up, 24.7% of the intervention group and 24.4% of the control group moved forward along the stages of change (unadjusted p = 0.96; adjusted p = 0.97).
No significant difference was seen in PTSD symptoms between groups at T2 (unadjusted p = 0.48; adjusted p = 0.36).
At T2, the intervention group had an average score of 54.5 (SD = 13.2, n = 62) on the PTSD Checklist and the control group had an average score of 55.9 (SD = 13.5, n = 59).
The intervention group experienced a greater decrease in PTSD symptoms at T3 compared with the control group (unadjusted p = 0.05; adjusted p < 0.01).

At T3, on the Baseline Characteristics Intervention (N = 89) % (n) unless otherwise specified Control (N = 86) % (n) unless otherwise specified p-value    PTSD Checklist, the intervention group had an average score of 58.4 (SD = 11.4, n = 61) and the control group had an average score of 62.4 (SD = 10.9, n = 59).
A statistically significant difference was seen in depression symptoms between groups at T2 (unadjusted p < 0.01; adjusted p < 0.01) and T3 (unadjusted p = 0.07; adjusted p = 0.02).
At T2, the intervention group had an average score of 7.9 (SD = 4.2, n = 68) on the GDS-SF and the control group had an average score of 10 (SD = 4.2, n = 62).
At T3, the intervention group had an average score of 8.4 (SD = 4.2, n = 61) and the control group had an average score of 9.8 (SD = 3.8, n = 59).

Intervention participants participated in a mean of 12.3 (SD = 5.5) MI counseling calls that lasted an average of 16.7 minutes (SD = 8.4, n = 87) and occurred over an average of 16.2 weeks (SD = 8.2).
Although both groups took longer than 90 days to complete the 90 Health Buddy sessions, there was no difference (p = 0.44).
Self-reported utilization of VHA smoking cessation treatments by participants who made a change to their smoking during the study was similar between groups during the study.

This pragmatic randomized controlled trial did not show a significant difference in 24 - hour quit attempts, seven-day PP smoking abstinence, and progression along the stages of change between the intervention and control groups.
We helped participants in both groups make changes to their smoking behaviors without negatively affecting PTSD symptoms and suicidal tendencies.
However, depression symptoms did improve in the intervention group during the intervention and follow-up periods.
The use of home telehealth is an effective way to integrate smoking cessation treatment into mental health services.
The study is limited by several factors.
Because the observed differences in the groups were not large and the confidence intervals around the RDs were wide, there could have been a difference between groups, but it was not discernible.
Our sample of mainly male, White, older participants may not be generalizable.
The small number of enrollees who responded to mail outreach recruitment efforts may have introduced a sampling bias.
Long-term cessation is not reported because we measured PP rather than continued abstinence and cessation was verified only during an appointment at T2 and T3.
Collecting data during the intervention period using home telehealth provided an easy way to gather data in both groups frequently; however, it resulted in methodological limitations.
Pragmatically, participants were permitted to choose how often to use the Health Buddy and talk with the nurse CM on the phone.
Some participants in both groups chose not to answer the Health Buddy everyday and others chose not to participate in the weekly telephone counseling sessions.
We did not track interactions between the control nurse CM and the control group participants.
Therefore, we do not know the quantity of smoking cessation conversations to which this group was exposed.
Neither the control nurse CM nor participants were blinded, so bias may have been introduced, which could have led to more smoking cessation conversations than usual care.
In conclusion, we believe the integration of MI-based smoking cessation care into home telehealth is an effective method to help Veterans with PTSD quit smoking.
This is evidenced by favorable smoking behavior changes in both intervention and control groups, despite the lack of a significant difference between groups.
Given the challenges this complex population faces when trying to quit smoking, this is an important finding.
However, additional research is required to understand how to optimize MI integration into home telehealth to achieve sustained smoking cessation rates.
